Award.AwardTitle: The Norse Settlement of the North Atlantic
Award.AbstractNarration: This project, PI Douglas Price, University of Wisconsin, will investigate the early migrations of Nordic peoples in the North Atlantic. Utilizing isotopic analysis of strontium, oxygen, and lead in tooth enamel from human remains the investigator will explore the paths of migration. This project is interdisciplinary and international, in addition to isotopic analysis the research team will also do DNA analyses on the available research specimens. The project will give new insights not only into the North Atlantic, but into fundamental questions regarding human exploration and colonization, the process of migration itself, and of course the movements of ancient Vikings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our project, called The Norse Settlement of the North Atlantic, was to learn about where the early settlers of the islands of the North Atlantic came from and when they arrived. The colonization of this area is a fascinating question, since these places — the Shetland, Orkney, and Faroe islands, Iceland, and Greenland, lie at the margins of habitability and were largely uninhabited before the Viking between 750 and 1000 AD. The colonization is also fascinating because of the extraordinary ship-building and navigation skills required to cross long distances in these treacherous waters.

 

Our project involved the use of isotopes in human and animal remains from archeological sites to study the colonization question. We collected samples of these remains from the islands of the North Atlantic and the potential homelands of the colonists in Scandinavia, Brtiain and Ireland. We used isotopes of radiocarbon to determine the age of some of the bones and help understand the timing of the colonization. We measured isotopes of strontium, oxygen, and lead in human tooth enamel from the colonists and compared that with similar data from their potential homelands in Norway, Sweden, Denmark, and the British Isles and Ireland.

 

Prior to the start of our project there was considerable debate about the origins of the settlers of Greenland and Iceland. One group of scholars followed the evidence of the Icelandic Sagas, arguing that Iceland was colonized by settlers from western Norway in a brief period of 60 years. Another group has argued that the settlers of Iceland were a mixed group from Scandinavia and the British Isles. Our results very much confirm the mixed model of settlement and point to the arrival of settlers from a variety of isotopic terrains, probably across the North Atlantic Rim of Europe. Radiocarbon dates and the variety of places represented among the settlers strongly implicate a longer period of settlement between 871 and 1000 AD. Interestingly, however, after 1000 AD and the introduction of Christianity on Iceland there appear to be very few new colonists.

 

On Greenland we are able to distinguish new colonists coming from Iceland and Scandinavia as well as document the import of cattle from Iceland to Greenland. Isotopic differences between the two major settlement areas on Greenland provide evidence of movement between the settlements and the return of settlers to Scandinavia. We were even able to distinguish individuals born in Greenland on their return to Norway.

 

The project has been a success. A large, international group of scholars and students from across the North Atlantic participated in the investigation of one of the more fascinating colonization movements in the human past and been able to document in some detail the origins of the colonists, the timing of the expansion, and the movement of individuals between colonies and homeland. Many new projects have spun off of the larger study, including the origins of Viking age people in Denmark and Sweden, the Viking expansion around the Baltic Sea and into Russia, and the origins and composition of human population at the first Viking town of Haithabu in northern Germany. A number of scientific publications have appeared or are in preparation as a result of this project. A final summary conference was held in the spring of 2010 and will appear as a volume publication of the Journal of the North Atlantic in 2012.
